trans-unit.source: "Squatting" on a package name that you plan to use, but aren't actually using. Sorry, I don't care how great the name is, or how perfect a fit it is for the thing that someday might happen. If someone wants to use it today, and you're just taking up space with an empty tarball, you're going to be evicted.
trans-unit.target: "Ponerse en cuclillas" en un nombre de paquete que planea usar, pero que en realidad no está usando. Lo siento, no me importa qué tan bueno sea el nombre, o qué tan perfecto sea para lo que algún día pueda suceder. Si alguien quiere usarlo hoy y estás ocupando espacio con un tarball vacío, serás desalojado.

trans-unit.source: "Starring" a package means that you have some interest in it. It's a vaguely positive way to show that you care.
trans-unit.target: "Protagonizar" un paquete significa que tiene algún interés en él. Es una forma vagamente positiva de demostrar que te preocupas.

trans-unit.source: "Unstarring" is the same thing, but in reverse.
trans-unit.target: "Unstarring" es lo mismo, pero al revés.

trans-unit.source: Private packages are always scoped.

Private packages can only be downloaded and installed by those who have been granted read access to the package. Since private packages are always scoped, you must reference the scope name during installation:
Scoped public packages can be downloaded and installed by anyone, as long as the scope name is referenced during installation:

trans-unit.source: Npm-In-CI – Set to "true" if npm believes this install is running in a continous integration environment, "false" otherwise. This is detected by looking for the following environment variables: CI, TDDIUM, JENKINS_URL, bamboo.buildKey. If you'd like to learn more you may find the original PR interesting. This is used to gather better metrics on how npm is used by humans, versus build farms.

Esto se detecta buscando las siguientes variables de entorno: CI , TDDIUM , JENKINS_URL , bamboo.buildKey . Si desea obtener más información, puede encontrar interesante el PR original . Esto se usa para recopilar mejores métricas sobre cómo los humanos usan npm, en comparación con la construcción de granjas.

trans-unit.source: [--dry-run] As of npm@6, does everything publish would do except actually publishing to the registry. Reports the details of what would have been published.

trans-unit.source: [--tag <tag>] Registers the published package with the given tag, such that npm install <name>@<tag> will install this version. By default, npm publish updates and npm install installs the latest tag. See npm-dist-tag for details about tags.

npm run sets the NODE environment variable to the node executable with which npm is executed. Also, if the --scripts-prepend-node-path is passed, the directory within which node resides is added to the PATH. If --scripts-prepend-node-path=auto is passed (which has been the default in npm v3), this is only performed when that node executable is not found in the PATH.
trans-unit.target: npm run establece el NODE variable de entorno para el node ejecutable con la que npm se ejecuta. Además, si se --scripts-prepend-node-path , el directorio dentro del cual reside el node se agrega a la PATH . Si se --scripts-prepend-node-path=auto (que ha sido el valor predeterminado en npm v3), esto solo se realiza cuando el ejecutable del node no se encuentra en la PATH .

npm token create [--read-only] [--cidr=<cidr-ranges>]: Create a new authentication token. It can be --read-only or accept a list of CIDR ranges to limit use of this token to. This will prompt you for your password, and, if you have two-factor authentication enabled, an otp.
trans-unit.target: npm token create [--read-only] [--cidr=<cidr-ranges>] : Crea un nuevo token de autenticación. Puede ser --read-only o aceptar una lista de rangos de CIDR para limitar el uso de este token. Esto le pedirá su contraseña y, si tiene habilitada la autenticación de dos factores, un otp.

trans-unit.source: npm token list: Shows a table of all active authentication tokens. You can request this as JSON with --json or tab-separated values with --parseable.
trans-unit.target: npm token list : muestra una tabla de todos los tokens de autenticación activos. Puede solicitar esto como JSON con --json o valores separados por --parseable con --parseable .

trans-unit.source: npm token revoke <token|id>: This removes an authentication token, making it immediately unusable. This can accept both complete tokens (as you get back from npm token create and will find in your .npmrc) and ids as seen in the npm token list output. This will NOT accept the truncated token found in npm token list output.
trans-unit.target: npm token revoke <token|id> : esto elimina un token de autenticación, dejándolo inutilizable inmediatamente. Esto puede aceptar tokens completos (como regresa de npm token create y encontrará en su .npmrc ) e identificadores como se ve en la salida de la npm token list . Esto NO aceptará el token truncado que se encuentra en la salida de la npm token list .

trans-unit.source: NOTE: npm versions 1 and 2 will automatically install peerDependencies if they are not explicitly depended upon higher in the dependency tree. trans-unit.source: Note: Since dist-tags share a namespace with semantic versions, avoid dist-tags that conflict with existing version numbers. We recommend avoiding dist-tags that start with a number or the letter "v".

Note: To make your package easier to find on the npm website, we recommend including a custom description in your package.json file.
Note: Two-factor authentication provides the best possible security for your account against attackers. We strongly recommend enabling 2FA on your account as soon as possible after you sign up.
Note: Using the recovery codes to re-enable 2FA may create a second authenticator account with the same npm account name.

Note: Vulnerabilities in npm packages should be reported directly to the package maintainers. We strongly advise doing this privately. You can find contact information about package maintainers with npm owner ls <package-name>. If the source code is hosted on GitHub please refer to the repository's Security Policy.

Note: We strongly recommend deprecating packages or package versions instead of unpublishing them, because unpublishing removes a package from the registry entirely, meaning anyone who relied on it will no longer be able to use it, with no warning.

Note: While access tokens are not derived from your password, changing your password will invalidate all of your tokens. You can also invalidate a single token by logging out on a machine that is logged in with that token. We recommend revoking rather than invalidating tokens.
Note: You can only publish unscoped packages to the npm public registry. You cannot publish unscoped packages to an npm Enterprise registry.
Note: You cannot change the visibility of an unscoped package. Only scoped packages with a paid subscription may be private.
Note: You cannot remove the developers team, learn more about the developers team.
Note: You must be using npm version 5.5.1 or greater to use access tokens.
Note: You must use the token ID to delete a token, not the truncated version of the token. In some cases, there may be a delay of up to an hour before a token is successfully revoked.
Note: You must verify your email address before you can publish packages to the registry.

trans-unit.source: Publish: The default setting for new tokens, and most permissive token type. Publish tokens allow installation, distribution, modification, publishing, and all rights that you have on your account.

Publish: a publish token can perform any action on your behalf, including downloading packages, publishing packages, and changing user settings or package settings. If you have two-factor authentication configured on your account, you will be required to enter a one-time passcode when using a publish token. This is recommended for interactive workflows.

trans-unit.source: Read-only: Tokens that allow installation and distribution only, but no publishing or other rights associated with your account.

Read-only: a read-only token can only be used to download packages from the registry. It will have permission to read any private package that you have access to. This is recommended for automation and workflows where you are installing packages, but not publishing new ones.

trans-unit.source: All data that passes through the cache is fully verified for integrity on both insertion and extraction. Cache corruption will either trigger an error, or signal to pacote that the data must be refetched, which it will do automatically. For this reason, it should never be necessary to clear the cache for any reason other than reclaiming disk space, thus why clean now requires --force to run.
trans-unit.target: Todos los datos que pasan a través de la caché se verifican por completo para verificar su integridad tanto en la inserción como en la extracción. La corrupción de la caché desencadenará un error o le pacote a pacote que los datos deben ser recuperados, lo que hará automáticamente. Por esta razón, nunca debería ser necesario borrar la caché por ningún motivo que no sea la recuperación de espacio en disco, por lo que clean ahora requiere --force para ejecutarse.

trans-unit.source: Any environment variables that start with npm_config_ will be interpreted as a configuration parameter. For example, putting npm_config_foo=bar in your environment will set the foo configuration parameter to bar. Any environment configurations that are not given a value will be given the value of true. Config values are case-insensitive, so NPM_CONFIG_FOO=bar will work the same. However, please note that inside scripts npm will set its own environment variables and Node will prefer those lowercase versions over any uppercase ones that you might set. For details see this issue.

Any environment variables that start with npm_config_ will be interpreted as a configuration parameter. For example, putting npm_config_foo=bar in your environment will set the foo configuration parameter to bar. Any environment configurations that are not given a value will be given the value of true. Config values are case-insensitive, so NPM_CONFIG_FOO=bar will work the same. However, please note that inside npm-scripts npm will set its own environment variables and Node will prefer those lowercase versions over any uppercase ones that you might set. For details see this issue.
trans-unit.target: Cualquier variable de entorno que comience con npm_config_ se interpretará como un parámetro de configuración. Por ejemplo, si coloca npm_config_foo=bar en su entorno, el parámetro de configuración foo se establecerá en bar . Cualquier configuración de entorno a la que no se le asigne un valor recibirá el valor de true . Los valores de configuración no distinguen entre mayúsculas y minúsculas, por lo que NPM_CONFIG_FOO=bar funcionará igual. Sin embargo, tenga en cuenta que dentro de npm-scripts npm establecerá sus propias variables de entorno y Node preferirá esas versiones en minúsculas sobre las mayúsculas que pueda establecer. Para obtener más detalles, consulte este número .

As an organization member, you can create and publish public and private packages within the organization's scope.

As an organization owner or team admin, you can also use the the CLI access command to revoke package access from a team on the command line:

As an organization owner or team admin, you can create teams to manage access to sets of packages governed by your organization.
As an organization owner or team admin, you can remove organization members from teams if they no longer need access to packages accessible to the team.

As an organization owner or team admin, you can remove teams that no longer need access to a set of packages governed by your organization. Removing the team will not remove the team members or packages from your organization.
As an organization owner or team admin, you can use the the CLI access command to add package access to a team on the command line:
As an organization owner, if you've made a mistake in inviting someone to your organization, you can revoke the organization invitation.

As an organization owner, you can add other npm users to your organization to give them read or read and write access to public and private packages within your organization's scope, as well as public unscoped packages governed by your organization.
As an organization owner, you can change the role of any member of your organization to add or remove permissions on the organization for that member.
As an organization owner, you can remove members from your organization if they are longer collaborating on packages owned or governed by your organization.

As an organization owner, you can update the email address used for receipts, and add extra information to the receipt for your paid organization plan, such as your business name, VAT identification number, or address of record. Updated billing information will appear on all receipts immediately.

As an organization owner, you can upgrade your free organization plan to the npm Teams product. npm Teams is a paid plan to give organization members the ability to install and publish private packages. For more information about npm Teams and our organization pricing plans, see the "npm Teams" section of our pricing page.
As an organization owner, you can view, download, and email receipts for the complete billing history of your organization.

As an owner of an npm Teams subscription, a paid organization plan, you can update the credit card used to pay for your plan. Updating your credit card will not change your billing cycle date, and the new credit card will be charged on the next billing cycle.

trans-unit.source: Because a token is simply a hexadecimal string, you can use the token in other tools, such as continuous integration testing environments, so that the tool can run with the access it needs to complete tasks. For example, Travis-CI provides an environment variable that you can assign to a token value. This gives Travis-CI the ability to run npm as your npm user, including the ability to install private packages to which you have access.
trans-unit.target: Dado que un token es simplemente una cadena hexadecimal,se puede utilizar el token en otras herramientas,como los entornos de pruebas de integración continua,para que la herramienta pueda funcionar con el acceso que necesita para completar las tareas.Por ejemplo,Travis-CI proporciona una variable de entorno que se puede asignar a un valor de token.Esto le da a Travis-CI la capacidad de ejecutar npm como su usuario npm,incluyendo la capacidad de instalar paquetes privados a los que tiene acceso.

trans-unit.source: By default, npm token create will generate a token with both read and write permissions. When generating a token for use in a continuous integration environment, we recommend creating a read-only token:
By default, any scoped package is published as private. However, if you have an organization that does not have the Private Packages feature, npm publish will fail unless you pass the access flag.

By default, npm installs from the primary npm registry, registry.npmjs.org. npm doctor hits a special ping endpoint within the registry. This can also be checked with npm ping. If this check fails, you may be using a proxy that needs to be configured, or may need to talk to your IT staff to get access over HTTPS to registry.npmjs.org.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, npm se instala desde el registro npm principal, registry.npmjs.org . npm doctor alcanza un extremo de ping especial dentro del registro. Esto también se puede comprobar con npm ping . Si esta verificación falla, es posible que esté utilizando un proxy que debe configurarse o que deba hablar con su personal de TI para obtener acceso a través de HTTPS a registry.npmjs.org .

trans-unit.source: By default, npm is installed alongside node in
trans-unit.target: Por defecto,npm se instala junto al nodo en

trans-unit.source: By default, other than latest, no tag has any special significance to npm itself.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, a excepción de la latest , ninguna etiqueta tiene un significado especial para npm.

trans-unit.source: By default, publishing a scoped package with npm publish will publish the package as private. If you are a member of an organization on the free organization plan, or are on the paid organization plan but want to publish a scoped package as public, you must pass the --access public flag:
By default, running npm publish will tag your package with the latest dist-tag. To use another dist-tag, use the --tag flag when publishing.
By default, scoped packages are private. To publish private modules, you need to be a paid private modules user.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, los paquetes con ámbito son privados. Para publicar módulos privados, debe ser un usuario de módulos privados de pago .

trans-unit.source: By default, scoped packages are published as private. You can read more about this in the scopes documentation.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, los paquetes con ámbito se publican como privados. Puede leer más sobre esto en la documentación de los ámbitos .

trans-unit.source: By default, scoped packages are published with private visibility.
By default, scoped packages are published with private visibility. To publish a scoped package with public visibility, use npm publish --access public.

By default, the latest tag is used by npm to identify the current version of a package, and npm install <pkg> (without any @<version> or @<tag> specifier) installs the latest tag. Typically, projects only use the latest tag for stable release versions, and use other tags for unstable versions such as prereleases.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, npm usa la latest etiqueta para identificar la versión actual de un paquete, y npm install <pkg> (sin ningún especificador @<version> o @<tag> ) instala la latest etiqueta. Por lo general, los proyectos solo usan la etiqueta latest para versiones de lanzamiento estables y usan otras etiquetas para versiones inestables, como prelanzamientos.

trans-unit.source: By default, the audit command will exit with a non-zero code if any vulnerability is found. It may be useful in CI environments to include the --audit-level parameter to specify the minimum vulnerability level that will cause the command to fail. This option does not filter the report output, it simply changes the command's failure threshold.

trans-unit.source: Caret ranges are ideal when an author may make breaking changes between 0.2.4 and 0.3.0 releases, which is a common practice. However, it presumes that there will not be breaking changes between 0.2.4 and 0.2.5. It allows for changes that are presumed to be additive (but non-breaking), according to commonly observed practices.

Sin embargo, se presume que habrá no haber cambios de ruptura entre 0.2.4 y 0.2.5 . Permite cambios que se presume que son aditivos (pero que no se rompen), de acuerdo con las prácticas comúnmente observadas.

trans-unit.source: Causes npm to install the package into your local node_modules folder with the same layout it uses with the global node_modules folder. Only your direct dependencies will show in node_modules and everything they depend on will be flattened in their node_modules folders. This obviously will eliminate some deduping. If used with legacy-bundling, legacy-bundling will be preferred.
trans-unit.target: Hace que npm instale el paquete en su carpeta local node_modules con el mismo diseño que usa con la carpeta global node_modules . Solo sus dependencias directas se mostrarán en node_modules y todo de lo que dependen se aplanará en sus carpetas de node_modules . Obviamente, esto eliminará algunas deducciones. Si se utiliza con legacy-bundling , legacy-bundling será preferido.

trans-unit.source: Causes npm to install the package such that versions of npm prior to 1.4, such as the one included with node 0.8, can install the package. This eliminates all automatic deduping. If used with global-style this option will be preferred.

trans-unit.source: Cleaning the slate
Clear login-related fields from ~/.npmrc – e.g., by running sed -ie '/registry.npmjs.org/d' ~/.npmrc
